review_title: Awful! Stay clear of this company!
job_title: Prefer To Remain Anonymous in Dyersburg, TN
pros: Making a difference in a child’s life.
cons: Not enough training nor internship. Had one and a half days of training with the “coach” and was shipped off to the center to begin working. Was told that I should have had more training done and read books on how to do paperwork for children’s files in the computer. When asking for help, I felt as though I was bothering the others in the center. Center was not staffed enough for teachers to have breaks and had to use the children’s bathroom when no one could step in to relieve the teacher. Don’t get me started on lesson plans, supplies for plans, not being able to print off coloring sheets related to the lessons ( God have mercy on your soul if you did!), and being told one thing by one person and the total opposite by someone that sits in an office all day and does zoom meetings. That person was supposed to come and evaluate me once a week for the firsts six months, but only had three evals done in five months. And I was expected to know my job like the back of my hand. All my evals were positive but with criticism due to lack of experience. I wonder why. This place is not a “head start”. It's nothing more than a glorified daycare started at the age of six weeks until the child moves on to real pre-k. If you look at all the available positions listed for STC, you have to wonder what is really going on within the company. Nothing is guaranteed to go in your favor, the children’s favor, nor the centers favor. It is all about what the numbers of children are for government funding and if the numbers are low for a center, funding can be cut.

pros: Incredible reach, involvement in global initiatives, donor affiliations, etc. Some teams/departments are good.
cons: Save the Children doesn't know what it wants to be when it grows up. As a result, it is a Frankenstein of an organization that doesn't do any one thing all that well (advocacy, charity, development, humanitarian aid). Affiliation with Save the Children International is a colossal mess. Save's bureaucracy outshines that of many of its competitors, which is saying a lot. You have a lot of people in leadership roles who are absolutely unqualified, who don't know anything about your setting, who have the authority to squash initiatives and whose own initiatives, which tend to be wasteful messes, get spotlight and investment. Culture is kind of a game of roulette, with some teams having decent collegiality, but most being pretty void of culture and connection. pros:
Organization has a large multi-sector portfolio which creates opportunities for cross-collaboration and learning between sectors
Has expressed commitment to localization and diversity
Great maternity/paternity policies and a competitive benefits pacakge
cons:
Issues with work life balance. Burnout and turnover are high due to constant sense of urgency.
No clear path for growth or promotion. How one gets promoted within the organization is opaque. Tendency to "pick winners", as appreciation is rarely given outside of select individuals, which is enabled by a lack of formal mentoring opportunities. Formal opportunities for professional development are limited. Resources are available for self-guided growth, but no guidance on what agency needs are and must be done on personal time.
There is a tendency to overly emphasize the importance of the written word. Prioritizes grammatical structure and narrative over communication
Project and staff needs do not match incentive structures. For example, there is no incentive for providing mentorship to others, or for your team to learn or grow. Incentives KPIs and quantity of outputs over quality. 
Save the Children lacks self-awareness on issues of class and power sharing. Class issues in international development are well documented but are not considered within DEI discussions. Power sharing is being done from the bottom up, not the top down. They are unaware that they will not be able to reach their diversity and localization goals if they do not embrace a diversity of economic backgrounds, schools attended, lived experience, regions, ways of thinking and working. Racial and ethnic minorities, and those with distinct lived experiences (often one in the same) will not thrive at this organization unless they embrace diversity as part of their work culture.

review_title: Good organization led astray by bad management
pros: Some dedicated and very capable group of staff who genuinely seek to do their best work. Lots of time off (if you're able to take it.)
cons:
The organization is currently in a transition period between a model where ownership of responsibilities was well distributed amongst its staff (meaning people were given the opportunity to take the ball and run with it and take ownership of their results) to a more distributed "top-down" hierarchical structure where individual contributions are not valued nearly as much. There is also a significant decrease in internal-staff investment.

What the above statement results in:
- Lots of new 3rd party off-shore consultants who are not very qualified or capable at executing needed duties. 

- A severe hit to morale amongst some departments and a corresponding brain-drain, where long-term and dedicated staff (former "lifers" who'd been there for decades) who were critical to certain functions are regularly leaving to new opportunities elsewhere. Replacement staff are nowhere near as capable.

- Massive internal confusion on how to execute against even the simplest of projects and objectives compounded with several new layers of largely ineffective or, in an increasing amount of cases, actively bad management

- Ability to execute severely and negatively impacted thanks to a lot of half-baked and poorly-conceived work methodologies designed by people who don't accept much, if any input from those "on the ground" and who won't be (and have never been) doing the actual work.

- Continuous internal reviews by management to understand why the latest work processes are failing without taking into account the input of those who are actually doing the work. This ultimately leads management to "fix" the wrong things, cause more delays and confusion, and generally and regularly decrease execution quality and speed and internal job satisfaction.

- While StC had always had some "egos" that put a big stamp on the organization, it was largely contained and had a nominal negative impact on the organization as a whole. Over the last ~2 years that has changed dramatically, where leadership appears no longer interested in making "what's best for StC" work but instead are more focused on making "what's best for me, my (post-StC) career, and my internal empire" work.

Only now that I am out, do I realize how toxic and unhealthy the environment was for me. 

When I first started with STC, almost a decade ago, I always wondered why would anyone leave company with such amazing and rewarding mission, fast forward to now, and the answer is, office politics! STC overall, has number of wonderful people working for them, who mostly represent charitable organizations, such as STC, in a positive light, however, in some departments, you can be Albert Einstein of your profession, but, if you belong to those of protected characteristics, or, even worse, have disability, or are of different nationality, you will get nowhere career wise.

From what I could see, STC was fully aware of this, and they are taking steps toward improvement. I hope they will be able to implement system and process, where it will be easy to report unethical behavior right away, and where the culprit can be identified and removed. 

 STC is a company with beautiful mission, and it is my hope that every child they work with, will be provided equal opportunity, regardless of race, nationality, or disability.

pros:
- Cannot stress enough how amazing the people are at SC. The colleagues I have worked with over the past 10+ years have mostly (barring a few) been professional, engaged and passionate individuals. 
- The organization is always on a path for continuous improvement and a lot of work has been done to address the antiquated IT systems and lack of diversity.
- If you are keen to learn, you will learn a lot. The organization is full of highly qualified staff with professional and technical backgrounds, who despite their degrees, have chosen low NGO salaries over making a lot more in other sectors. 
- HR senior staff are incredibly professional and helpful (not usual among HR in many other places).
cons:
- The current CEO has implemented extremely drastic changes in a very short time, without any regard for proper change management. 
- The changes that were made have had/will continue to have negative impact on SCUS and US based staff, in favor of having a positive impact on Save the Children International, again an unusual decision by a CEO to harm her own staff in favor of another entity.
- An exodus of talent (almost a hemorrhage) has depleted the organization of much needed talent over the past year, doubling the work load for many people and making it extremely stressful to reach targets without the right structure and support. No accommodations in strategy, planning or management were considered to support staff through this.
- The CEO has a heavy handed, non-people approach, which is in contradiction with the mission of the organization and makes it difficult to bring up issues to your immediate managers knowing they are mostly disempowered.

review_title: Wonderful, leading world organization with a powerful change-making mission
pros:
The Mission of the organization is spectacular -- to deliver the most needed and life-saving aid, to the most vulnerable and marginalized group-- children in the poorest circumstances and hardest disasters -- is inspiring, moving, and touching. It feels great to be part of a team that has such strong impact directly and quickly. It makes every day fulfill and is work to be proud of. It truly lives up to its phenomenal mission, values, and high level of true ambition. 

The organization is a top, leading world class and renowned organization. It is standard setting, very versatile, does so much, and has technical expertise in many fields and area (thematic, regional, functional, etc.). It also produces stellar evidence based research for what methods of aid are most effective. Easy one of the best in the industry and among any competitors. 

The co-workers are extremely intelligent diverse, come from amazing backgrounds in the development field, other top organizations, and have a positive, collaborative attitude where they help each other all the time. It is solid teamwork and care, which makes it a pleasure to work with the staff.

The organization takes good care of its employees and truly cares about them -- through the benefits, social events, and activities organized for its employees (around diversity, mental health, etc). Managers and leadership are often checking in with their teams to make sure all is okay -- especially during challenging COVID times.
cons:
Things still move slowly -- there are many processes, rules, regulations that slow down work, potentially compromising efficiency. This is understandable because of all the necessary and needed safeguards from working with government and intergovernmental organization grants, which tend to have major stipulations. Also understandable when working with vulnerable groups.

 However, there must be a better balance between efficiency and the regulations. Often even 1 task goes through so many staff members/ departments to be completed -- this is for accountability, but can often be excessive and too much. -- And I work in one of the fastest pace departments where we are making the most changes. This creates the corporate/ bureaucratic that others may be mentioning.

- Also 403B benefits don't start until 1 year of work :/

review_title: Not a place for jr. staff
pros: Everyone is really mission driven and the work  is meaningful.
cons: The management team has a very specific idea of what path junior staff should take and they are not willing to work with the skills and interests of the specific employee. Staff (at all levels) are actively told to leave and come back in order to move up instead of promoting their internal talent, even though the organization supposedly champions promoting from within. HR discussions about workplace culture  and upward mobility are actively discouraged within the Department of Global Health. Several employees have been told that talking to HR makes them look bad or that advocating for themselves makes them look impatient.  How salaries are determined is very unclear and often made more confusing than it needs to be.  Pay is not equitable at all-- even within the same role in the same department.

review_title: On the contrary: This is an awesome place to work
pros: With so many bad reviews, I wanted to shed some light on the truth on the company and our Houston Tx branch. With my time at the Houston office, I  met so many wonderful people who taught me so many things either in the professional or personal aspect.  I had the opportunity to support many different communities in so many inquire ways. I have never been so proud to represent a company, especially when they community took time out to honor me for my job.  The negative comments to not do this company and branch justice.  90% of my colleges were really good people and continue to do good work despite the challenges. The core values of Accountability, Creativity, Ambition, Collaboration and Integrity are definitely  practiced  within the company They are also  very generous with time off, employee appreciation event, raises, opportunities for travel, career growth and education, and many additional things.
cons: The only cons about our office was It was really rewarding until a couple bad eggs changed the culture of our work. They did not follow the values of the company therefore our team to not get the support needed from them but from others in our office and the company while still being constrained.  Do not not let the reviews turn you away from this company and the Houston branch but I will say being in the same environment with those couple of bad eggs is not where you want to be right now.

pros: Overall mission is great and there seems to be genuine  engagement and feeling from senior leadership in the issues. Great people to work with (for the most part) who are smart, dedicated, and there for the right reasons. Large reach globally with lots of in-house expertise.
cons: Too many priorities focused on fundraising and not enough support for programmatic growth/excellence. Top-heavy with senior management. For salaries, it doesn't seem HR/hiring managers give offers based on years of experience and role against other staff at same level...leading to very different starting salaries. The value placed on salary history is frustrating when many people often inflate their past history.  Career growth varies widely by department (finance, fundraising, new business, comms teams seem to promote staff quickly with limited years of experience, while programmatic teams tend to stagnate). New systems/focus rolled out without thinking through support that is really needed to make them effective.

review_title: Hypocrisy, abuse abound at Save the Children
job_title: Director, Human Resources in Washington, DC
pros: The mission of Save the Children is to provide lasting and positive change for children.  There is no argument that this is a worthy cause.   Many, many children and families' lives have been changed for the better due to the amazingly good work of the staff of STC.  The commitment and passion shown for those in need is amazing.
cons: STC manages today as it did 35 years ago.  Rather than  a decision making process based on truth, facts and ROI's, decisions are based on political connections,  tenure within the organization and how much money will it raise.  Abusive, hostile treatment of employees is commonplace.  Discrimintory practices are ignored, even when raised to Sr. Management.  Fiscal responsibility is shallow  at best.  The HR department in Westport, CT is incompetent, and in need of an audit.  There are violations of  USAID requirements as well as EEO requirements.  For an organization that employs more than 6,000 and has been around for 75 years, I was shocked by what I found.

pros:
I have worked for Save the Children for over 7 years. It is a relaxed, fun, supportive and family-friendly work environment. The leadership (including C-suite) are all very approachable and transparent with staff and with their decision-making processes.  There is also a culture of addressing problems head-on and moving forward, which I have not seen in many other organizations. 

The benefits are wonderful, with generous leave, including family leave, community-service leave and generous retirement benefits.
cons:
1. Although I've been happy with my salary, the buzz in the business is that our salaries are low compared to the industry standard. 

2. For international work, the bureaucracy makes it difficult to get things done and move money and work to field offices. 

3. New CEO starting in January 2020, so there is some uncertainty about the direction this will take the organization. 

4. Opportunities for growth are limited and although there is a lot of racial and ethnic diversity in rank and file employees, the higher up you go, the "whiter" the organization it gets.

pros: As above title in review
cons: No cons to report of

review_title: Amazing people, great mission...and some pockets of terrible
pros: The folks I had the pleasure of calling colleagues were awesome. Motivated, smart, creative and fun to be around, the people are the best part. If you have the right boss and the right team, it can be a great place to build your career.  Carlos and Carolyn are visible leaders who create opportunities for staff to share feedback (no matter your tier in the org chart), and while it's a tricky one for such a big organization (300-ish in DC, 300-ish in CT and 100-ish in KY? or more? I never really knew), the communications internally got better while I was there.
cons: That said, there are pockets of terrible. Whether it's a bad VP or getting stuck on a team that doesn't value you, there are a few teams that I would steer my friends away from applying to.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ḩawwārah, Amman Governorate
pros: I wouldn't like for these experience, that the staff not kindest at all, that they afraid from every each thing for do it, that made them afraid of suggestions or creativity in their field of work, the P&C they have a distinction in dealing in a remarkable manner, the logistic they not cooperation with their  colleagues. I've been experiencing  in 4 companies before Save the Children but I had never faced what I faced in this NGO, Unfortunately.
cons: I don't like to wakeup in the morning cues i will see people who's never treating in a good way, not helpful or coop rations, that made me I don't like what I do, and made me chair down every day and I would the week finish every Morning, the manager he has not been any democratic in his way or in his meetings or in his

pros: Dedicated and committed people who give their best day in, day out despite the enormous difficulties within the organisation. Nice office in a great location.
cons:
It's difficult to pinpoint exactly the issues within Save, but to put it simply the organisation doesn't feel like it particularly cares about the individuals that work there. You are there to do a job, that's it. If you don't do, someone else will come in and do it.

From the poorly implemented hot-desking which stops you putting down roots of any kind, to the woefully incompetent HR team which has even higher turnover than the rest of the organisation, to the generally accepted culture of working staff into the ground until they leave, Save feels like it runs on brand strength alone.

I left just as a new Chief Exec was coming in, who may well change this. But from my time at Save I couldn't recommend it.

pros: Save the Children is one of the pinnacle leaders in the humanitarian  industry.   The leadership is transparent about decision making.  I get respect when I tell people I work for Save the Children.  I have traveled to some amazing places in my career here and met some amazing people.  I have learned a lot in my time here.
cons:
While Save the Children's revenue last year was 640 million only a small portion of that revenue is in the form of unrestricted/ undesignated funds.  Consequently the organization is constantly having to make hard choices when it comes to funding operations..  Some people lost their jobs last year because of it.

Because all international operations were consolidated into a separate organization (Save the Children International) there are less international career opportunities.

pros: There is not much positive to say about my engagement as a consultant for Save the Children. I felt quite isolated in working remotely and it was hard to see impact of my work. My counterpart has answered all my emails on time and seemed overall committed to the process.
cons:
I have now waited for over 4 months to be paid on a short term contract despite fulfilling all requirements and handing in all assignments on time. This is an unacceptable treatment of small contractors and independent consultants who are dependent on their clients to pay on time. 

The HR number in the UK never works and my counterpart in the organisation has shielded me from engaging directly with the Finance Team and thus left me stranded with empty promises such as "I'll follow up" and "You'll get your money soon'.

pros: Work / life balance can be achieved depending upon the individual manager/supervisor you report to.  Some were quite flexible and supportive while many others were quite against it.  This completely surprised me given the core mission of the organizaiton - promoting the care and well being of mothers and children across the globe.
cons: Extremely political and surprisingly cliquey.  If you were not a part of the "in crowd" your ideas for improvements were ignored or ridiculed.  Also the organization relies heavily - too heavily - on decision-making by consensus.  If it's nearly impossible to get 2 people to agree upon a decision/conclusion, imagine the chaos when you need to include 10+.  The organization needs to come to terms with the fact that its growth has positioned it to operate more like a for-profit entity and not a collective 'kumbaya' club.  IMO

pros: Wanting to be a part of something that helps children worldwide is a good thing and there are some people who work here that truly do have that calling.  Unfortunately, I did not get a sense that all donor dollars where used to benefit children.
cons: Constant layoffs and reorganizations; everyone feels stressed out about what might happen next; constant problems with computer systems that never seem to get fixed; unrealistic business objectives and goals that are constantly changing; poor upper management leadership/decisions; too many high paid managers who would be considered totally incompetent in the for-profit world yet are kept on the payroll for years; endless hours of unproductive meetings; very political environment - its who you know rather than your job performance; a few do most of the work at very little pay; some can job hop/work from home while others cannot; they make a big deal out of their performance review process but don't back it up with any training or advancement options-its really meaningless paperwork.

review_title: My experience working for Save the Children has been mostly positive.
pros: Save the Children is a family-oriented nonprofit that values mobility across departments. The organization has a strong mission and values focused on helping children in the US and abroad through emergency response and longer-term development programs.
cons: It is challenging to get promoted within your unit. Positions become available based on business needs. It is very rare if a new role or promotion comes about as a result of the performance of an individual. So, employees typically have to be willing to apply for jobs in other areas, wait for a superior to leave, or luck out if a new job is created in order to move up in the organization.

review_title: Good experience but bad work environment (I'm not talking about the HQ in UK or US)
pros: You learn a lot, you have colleagues with good ideas (some of them, mostly the field staff, they are very committed and really nice people). Very transparent with the use of funds.
cons: The work environment was a nightmare, a lot of gossips, a very vertical structure between the HQ and the country offices. Within the country offices, more vertical structure. The SMT in my office was very inefficient . The worst co-worker I have ever had was in this organization, everyone knew it but they did not call her attention. However, I saw how they fired other colleagues for reasons that were not so justified.

pros: The corporation seems wonderful, the benefits were good, and I believe the company as a whole does good work.
cons: Completely mismanaged; it’s as if a big pile of money landed in their lap and they had no clue what to do. The original mission changed and those who were offered help never received it leaving a bad taste in my mouth. It was basically a bunch of people sitting around with plans but no actions.  Middle management was a joke and preferred to sit back and get a check rather than get out and work. The project I was on was supposed to last 2 years but could’ve easily been done in 1 but they wanted to stretch it out to 3.

review_title: Great people, but you have to like a large organization
pros: Really excellent people and mid and even some upper management positions, generally working for the mission, some great progress on key strategies, pretty good sharing of information.
cons: Can be very political at the upper management level, staff can get lost in the domestic offices. There is sometimes too much emphasis on image, sometimes some really bad communication from senior management about tough decisions, and sometimes a bit clubby with the people who've been around for a long time. But generally the good largely out weighs the bad by far.

pros: Family friendly policies and  great mission helping children
cons: Sr Mgt doesn’t understand nuances of business and makes decisions w/o being informed.  They have a lot of reorganizations which cause workplace chaos that goes on for months and a brain drain with talented staff leaving.

pros: Save takes a very professional approach to its work, which I haven't seen in a lot of non-profits.  The pay is average for large non-profits and the benefits are very good - lots of vacation, holiday and sick time.  There are lots of opportunities to take online courses within the organization for professional development.
cons: Change is constant.  Because of this, people are always afraid they are losing their job or that some other similar department will make them obsolete.  Some departments are more responsive than others.  These are all common workplace issues though.

review_title: Experiences can be very different from team to team
pros: There are not enough great things to say about Save the Children's work, the technical output is very impressive and allows Save to stay a key player in the development world. There are a lot of bright people who are very passionate about their work.
cons: Each employees experience is entirely different based on what team you are on, with little mobility or opportunity to move teams. Some teams are wonderful and do amazing work, while others will make your life miserable. There is a hierarchy with extremely poor senior leadership that does not do enough to support junior staff and very little room for career mobility. The lack of support for junior staff leads to high turn over, the organization views a lot of its junior staff as disposable.

review_title: Nice work, but a little frustrating
pros: Work for a great cause, meet nice people that wants to help. Nice colleagues. Develop your mind by convincing someone to donate in 5 minutes. Develop your capacity to deal with  frustration (you receive so many "nos" in the work hours. When you make many new donors, the salary is good, given that it is a part time
cons: Too many people does not even answer to you, so it is very frustrating. It generates anxiety for the commission based-salary, especially in the beginning of the month. If the donation did not started as supposed, but they already payed you, in the following months they take the money back

review_title: Fantastic organization, and great place to work. You make an impact.
pros: This organization is truly dedicated to making life better for all kids, no matter where they are. They do what is right. The leadership is great, most people are collaborative and like working with each other.
cons: As with any non profit, there's pressure to raise money so you can do more to advance the mission. That can be stressful at times. Also, you're dealing with tough conditions for these kids, so it can be overwhelming to know how much is wrong with how we treat children around the world. But the pros fully outweigh the cons.

pros: Getting to work with a wide range of people through volunteering, I especially enjoyed interacting with older members of my community and hearing their stories. Working towards a common goal.
cons: Sometimes as a volunteer you may feel  you're working very hard for an outcome you're unsure about, you have to remember most contributions are towards long term goals. Also, stress of dealing with rude customers in retail - but not being paid to do so! Takes a certain level of determination to be a shop volunteer.

pros: Decent Office Space, Ok Benefits
cons: Can't say that I had the most positive experience at Save the Children's DC Office. While they moved into a new building on North Capitol St. this location was just horrible and reduced privacy tremendously. It is a call center set up with VP's sitting at desk right in the open, so if you think you will have some sort of privacy, think again. Professionally, this was by far the worst experience I've had so far. Would you think with this being a humanitarian organization people would be a bit more friendly. Unfortunately, the atmosphere was very cold, jaded and dry. People walked down the hall, turned their noses up at you and didn't speak at all. I'm a very social person and while I do not look to make friends at work, I expect the environment to be professional and cordial. Wrong again with this place.  I guess this attitude was passed down from the CEO because she was not friendly at all. She would barely acknowledge staff she did not know and if she did, it was cold and wasn't genuine. Fortunately, the Executive Vice President Carlos made up for that with his very bright, warm and welcoming personality. LOVED interacting with him as he was such a loving person.  They experience a HIGH turnover here too due to lack of donor funding, so if you are looking for a position with longevity, this is NOT the place. If you are a part of the business functions you might stay, however the projects come and go with the wind. The department I worked for was full of conservative, mildly offensive professionals. They were cold, rude and the VP acted as if he did not know how to run his department. The entire environment was just suspect and I would NOT recommend this place to work. They do AMAZING work, but the culture here? TERRIBLE! Don't get me started on senior management....

pros:
A great mission and flexible work schedule. A lot of "Career training" available. If you need a flexible work schedule this is the place - for a while. 

Competitive salary for a non-profit. 

The underlying desire is there among most employees to really make a difference in the lives of children and tends to attract some very smart and interesting people.
cons:
Terrible Senior Management, No Career Movement, Participation in "Career Training Programs" ultimately leads to no career movement. 

Many of the Senior management tend to create an unnecessarily competitive environment which lead to a tense working situation. The struggle to be recognized among mid managers lead to an almost impossible environment for teamwork and ultimately very unprofessional behavior. 

To anyone who both wants to make a difference and is also career oriented, Save the Children is a mixed bag. Yes its a great mission. Unfortunately the organization is a career killer and most of the talent realize this after a few years and jump ship to other organizations. Senior management accountability is almost non existent.

pros: Child- and outcome-focused.  Really getting the work done!  Good strong history and legacy.  Smart and talented leaders (some).  Good benefits if in the field (not so great for US-based staff).  Good reputation.  Diverse funding base (and not overly reliant on USG funding).
cons: Long hours, can be difficult to balance work/life.  Travel can be extensive.  Consensus-building management atmosphere (and consensus-building is really just about getting to lowest common demoninator).

review_title: Mismanagement is endemic, employee development is not a priority, and creative, hardworking individuals are not valued.
pros: Pay is good for a nonprofit, the reputation (deserved or not) looks good on your resume, and the people who are not in management positions tend to be very bright, friendly, passionate and hardworking.
cons:
Leadership is completely lacking, and individuals at a Director or VP level shun decision making.  This would be ok if the rest of the organization was allowed to work to its true productivity, but alas, Save the Children managers tend to focus much more on keeping their positions and stifling creative ideas (a culture of "business as usual") than on employee development.  It's too bad, because the number of excellent people coming into the organization is phenomenal, and they tend to leave within a year or less.  Unless you plan to be field based, this is not a place where you will grow professionally.

Save the Children needs to figure out a way to work within its mission.  It is becoming impossible to see the difference between Save the Children, Mercy Corps and CARE.  The concentration on rampant fundraising (especially with US Government money) instead of on what people really want and need (supposedly the backbone of development and humanitarian work) is beyond disheartening.  Save the Children will chase any money that is tossed before it.

Lastly, the finance department is a mess and it makes the working lives of anyone who has to depend at some point on finance for clear policies or guidance very difficult.

review_title: Great mission can be tough organisation to work in
pros: I worked in the Save the Children UK office for around 3 years in the communications division. Had some amazing opportunities to travel and there was a real sense of organisational mission. Great colleagues too.
cons:
Can be a lot of pressure from senior management to meet targets. 
Sometimes felt like we were achieving big campaign launch moments not to deliver any practical result (money or policy win) but for the sake of it. 
No clear promotion route for my role.

pros: An organization with a clear mandate and a good number of genuinely impressive people especially in education.
cons: Shifted to being overly corporate during the past 2-3 years. Too large and detached from beneficiaries as a result of the SCI movement, and much too focused on efforts to develop "strategy" verses maintaining a critical focus on actual implementation of effective projects. Growth opportunities afforded to individuals are severely curtailed. Significant declines in incomes and new awards due to misguided new business directions will have serious impact on long term health of the organization.

pros: They give you the chance to work on mission driven projects
cons:
In effect, there are no real meaningful protections for employees. They have policies and procedures that benefit the organization at the complete disadvantage of the employee. Case in point: you could easily log 80+ hours in a week, travel or work two weekends in a row and receive NO comp time. All of this is at the discretion of the manager. 
Compensation is embarrassing and benefits don’t make up for the fact that many of us end up working for minimum wage after all is said and done.

review_title: An office that feels like home and co-workers who feel like family
pros:
- Colleagues are incredibly supportive and collaborative even under incredibly high stress circumstances such as emergencies or crises in the field
- Work life balance is respected and workers are never admonished for needing to tend to their personal lives.
- Lots of opportunity to grow and develop within the organization
- Benefits are unreal, they really take care of you here
cons:
- Budgetary constraints due to the nature of the organization 
- Fairly meeting heavy and somewhat complicated structure which can be confusing to navigate
- Frequent re-orgs

pros: Save the Children has a great mission and offers strong programs throughout the world.  I also like that they work in the US.  There is a professional working environment and the management has people with a lot of experience.
cons: It seems like money coming in is the only thing that matters.  They burn through senior positions very quickly and it causes a lot of instability and uncertainty for everyone else.

review_title: Things Will Not Change until Top Management Changes
pros:
- build professional relationships with most of the people I work with;
- flexibility of work schedule [usually] when there are emergencies with family/kids;
cons:
- it seems the finance department is a mess, there is a lack of leadership. When you have folks in management roles for 20-30 years, innovation and change go out the window - no, these aren't even allowed at the door. Many new people come in, but they are also the first to leave. Either these "lifers" need to switch to another department for a while or start an exchange program with other NGOs, to get some fresh blood in there, but nothing will change until the senior finance folks change - and sadly, it doesn't look like any of 'em will leave soon. Westport isn't exactly the HUB for NGOs, ya know. Forget it if you are a woman! The top finance folks will use the passive-agressive behaviour technique to force you out. You could have great ideas, but if the senior managers are the ones responsible for the idea:  forget it.  B-Level managers DO NOT hire A-level staff here. It's more like C-level managers though and they ain't hiring anyone who will outshine or outperform them.
- Get rid of the conflicts of interest and nepotism. This ain't a family business. Husbands and wives working in the same department - come on. Uncles, cousins, sister-in-laws being hired or brought in from overseas?  There are many many qualified Americans who can do the work.. Oh yeah, it makes it hard to have a disagreement with a co-worker if her husband is your boss:  can you say conflict of interest????!!!  Cut the nepotism and put a conflict of interest policy in place
- Lack of transparency:  people are given promotions or new positions without a new position being advertised. As for hiring, if you are in a clique, don't worry about applying for new positions because you can earn a new position even if you aren't qualified. you just have to be in the "clique."
- Lack of follow up from HR when one interviews for a position. You usually find out from the Announcment Page when someone has been hired for a position for which you were interviewed. HR needs to get back to candidates BEFORE announcing who has been selected to fill a position.
- Lack of direction with this whole Save the Children International thing - there has been such a lack of communication from mangement downwards; lack of planning; there are plans in place, but the senior management doesn't want to share with staff - like they feel empowered by holding information. Managers don't work with employees to get them into other positions (probably cause they are looking at protecting their own jobs)
- Performance Evaluations - they have a quota of how many people can get each rating. So regardless of how highly your supervisor may think of your performance, if the senior managers don't want you to get a high rating, you ain't gonna get it. year after year, my supervisor comes back to apologize that his/her evaluation of me what rejected because the rating was too high.
- Misuse of funds - when you see photos of children who look like they are starving, don't think all your donations reach them...there are $60,000 + vehicles being purchased for employee use to take their children to/fm the private schools or $4,200/month homes being rented, swimming pools that need to be cleaned; best thing is to designate your contributions to a specific cause

review_title: A good place to start, but not to grow
pros: The mission is an important one, and you can be confident that the money you raise is going to programs.
cons: LONG working days - 9-530 with 1/2 for lunch. Who does that? There is an expression - penny wise and pound foolish, and Save does that. They skimp and skimp and don't put money where it's needed. Silos are strong, even in teams, and it's maddening. The pay is also low, even for non-profits.

job_title: Donor Services Specialist in Fairfield, CT
pros: The work is absolutely rewarding. At the end of the day you leave feeling satisfied and accomplished knowing that you contributed to the greater good on a global scale. Pay is good and time off appropriate.
cons: Staff seems nice but there is a very snooty undertone. Calls are timed so it’s difficult informing donors of all of the rewards their contributions offer. Around the Christmas holiday season work is stressful with extremely high call volume-with lots of employee turnover in the sponsorship and donor services area with inexperienced telephone operators. Most of these are good problems.

review_title: The most traumatic period in my life...
pros: The work they do is truly incredible; so many children are assisted through their programs!
cons: I'm not sure about the other offices, but the DC office was a total disaster. The leadership treats "junior" staff like utter trash, they refuse to let people speak up without retaliating against them, they are snarky/rude. I left Save the Children in 2019, and have joined another organization. I just want to say, I am finally at peace and realize how toxic that environment was for my health and overall wellbeing.

review_title: Am readily available and have passion to safe keep of children
pros: I love working with children and for their safe upkeep and make the better world for them
cons: i don't like when children are being forced to marry at a tender age and not allowed to go to school especially girls

pros: This is a great job if you love to work with children.  You get the opportunity to watch them grow and help them learn new things.
cons: PAPERWORK.  Too many bosses, telling other bosses what to do and how, so much that the message always gets changed and the staff gets blamed every time.

pros: Great people who are passionate, determined, and extremely intelligent. Flexible working hours. 21 days of paid vacation plus 10 paid sick days.  Management who care about the well being of their staff. The office is a lot of fun as well. If you're someone who likes to work independently and make their own way, it's an ideal space.
cons: Sometimes not good communication beetween departments. Salary are quite low, but is good for an NGO.

review_title: Great Mission, but revolving door of staff
pros:
Amazing mission
Truly changing lives around the world
Diversity of Staff really keeps you interested in the work.
Seriously qualified staff
cons:
Leadership positions are constantly vacating and being restaffed
This leads to multiple strategy changes
Salaries are not near competitors in NYC or other metro areas
Typical Bureaucratic issues when trying to accomplish a project

pros: Mission of helping kids, truly smart and devoted people, a wonderfully engaged board of trustees and the ability to make real change in the world.
cons: Leadership is stale. The ceo lacks vision and has presided over 5 years of no growth. C-level executives lack managerial courage and cannot make difficult decisions around prioritization. Hopefully a new board chair will start a leadership change.

review_title: Great people, but lack of job mobility
pros: The people are wonderful and the location is convenient. Great network to be a part of. The name of the organization is valuable.
cons: There is a lack of professional development, the organization does not encourage job mobility or development of its support staff.

pros: This internship varies highly from intern to intern. I would recommend it for undergrad students, but maybe not for those in graduate school.  Some interns worked a lot and had a great experience, but I was on the opposite end of that spectrum.
cons: I barely got any work and was completely underutilized.

pros: I'm proud to work at Save the Children and for an ogranization that helps to improve the quality of peoples life.  Vacation is generous, if you can use it.
cons: If you aren't one of the "in crowd" you won't get anywhere.  If you want to settle, it's the place to work.

pros: Country Office staff were in the most part incredibly dedicated and inspiring people to work with. Much of the work on the ground really was leading the way in the sector & indeed within the UK office itself, there were leading world class advisors at our fingers tips.
cons: Senior management cliques at UK office - unnecessary in fighting and point scoring. Huge decisions made with little regard of the impact at country level.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Fairfield, CT
pros: Great mission. Opportunity to grow. Ability to travel and see the world.Fantastic colleagues. Collegial, non political environment. Summer Fridays out at 2:00 every other week.
cons: Complex work with a lot to learn. Can be difficult to navigate the many priorities. Essential to have strong influencing skills.

pros:
Like the non-hierarchal office spaces. (Leaders sit in open desks and cubicles.)
Staff are pleasant and HR does a good job in trying to create a fun and friendly atmosphere.
cons:
Lack of training. They throw  you into projects with no training and hope you float. 
Low salaries compared to other international development orgs.
Highly under-resourced in terms of staff. Creates dysfunction, long hours and overworking (Compared to other NGOs). Work life balance is non-existent.
CT office needs more diversity

pros:
1. Comfortable working environment
2. Work-life balance (8 hours means 8 hours, need not stay back unless there is any urgent/priority job that needs to be done)
3. Best place to learn and grow for people at the beginning of their careers
4. Feeling of satisfaction, that you are working for a good cause.
cons:
1. System needs to be restructured as number of people in every department ends up doing repetitive work.
2. Sometimes too relaxed environment also limits an individuals growth

pros: Save the Children supports children around the world
cons:
Benefits/policies directly contradict the science and evidence, along with the very principles of Save the Children. Examples: Parental leave benefits are inhumanely minimal and ultimately put young children and mothers in danger. 
Policies are applied haphazardly. It's unclear who gets to work from home, who gets comp time, etc. This dynamic has made favoritism rampant at work.

pros: Great mission and impact on the lives of children
cons: Toxic culture, poor leadership, lack of focus, diversity and inability to make decisions.  The work environment encourages employees to work in silos,  is  highly competitive, political and employees will do anything to get ahead.  There is no courage or willingness to address bad behavior, bullying, exclusion and poor leadership.

review_title: Some Great People But Little Upward Mobility
pros: Made some great friends, had some interesting travel opportunities. They felt like my family for the many years I worked there.
cons: Upper management--lots of changes. Getting used to the pace and vibe of new bosses all the time is tiring, and also affects one's ability to move up.  Layoffs and restructuring seems to happen every few years.

pros: Employee friendly policies. Great field exposure.
cons:
Senior managers and directors not qualified. No leadership qualities among seniors. Only coordinators,officers and asdistants do all work. No learning and development. 

A lot of leg pulling. Non existent intra and interdeparmental communication. A lot of ego among managers. Everything is outsourced and you actually become iron developing rust. You JUST take salary and do admin and clerical work mostly.

pros: Senior management is very accessible and friendly. They will always say hi when they pass you in the hallway and strike up conversations just to hear your thoughts, how you're doing, etc. I've never worked anywhere that had such accessible senior management staff. Work-life balance is fairly decent, depending on the department you're in. Most of the staff are very nice, especially IT, benefits, HR.
cons: Too many to list. Basically, don't work here, at least not now or for the next 5-10 years. The old boys club still exists at the middle level of management and they protect each other at all costs, at great expense to those at the support level who actually do the work. No one can tell what these managers actually do; looks like nothing. It might be better when these people retire in 5-10 years, but I'd doubt it. Misogyny and ageism abound. If you're a younger woman just be prepared to be treated like crap and like a moron from your superiors, meanwhile your male counterparts can basically do nothing and get away with it. Forget about promotions; unless you're in upper level management it's not possible. There's no transparency to the process. The organization actively works to try to cut your salary at great effort and any time someone leaves and the job is reposted it's always at a lower level for less pay. There's no upward mobility. Except for a handful of nice people, the environment is toxic. You're encouraged to act like you're in middle school and talk behind each other's backs. Just don't come here, seriously. It's not worth it. I'm getting out of here as soon as I can.

review_title: A great learning opportunity but understand when to leave

A lot of learning opportunities 
The work and mission are phenomenal
cons:
Widespread favoritism and mismanagement 
Really limited ability to move up in most positions

review_title: Opportunities to be involved in change processes
pros: Dedicated, passionate colleagues.  Inspiring programs to improve lives of children.  Regularly asking - what can we do more for children?  (Which means there are opportunities to adjust ways of working)

pros: You really can't get a better mission than Save's.
cons: Going into Save I'd like you to understand a few real experiences. First, in December 2019 a mid-level HR staff member sent a note to all Save/US staff working overseas informing them that Save has dramatically miscalculated their tax withholdings.  In my case, the mistake was equivalent to 5 months of take home pay. This is but the worst incident in a long string of payroll errors I encountered. My pay has fluctuated between receiving paychecks that are literally $0.00 to a few hundred to a couple of thousand. This relates to a few issues around salary and benefits to Save/US staff posted overseas. Other errors have included paying benefits for months beyond the date they are supposed to be paid and then forcing me to repay for months...and then making errors on the number of months needed to repay. I personally caught many of these not inconsequential errors. Save senior management has evidently taken the advise of their lawyers and decided to not effectively help their employees put in serious binds by Save's accounting errors. This underscores the character of the senior leadership team that hides behind processes and fails to engage real employee complaints. Do not work with Save unless you  have savings and can weather the serious financial mistakes the organization can make with your pay, benefits, and taxes. If you want an idea of how Save responds to complaints, read the responses on this website. There's a lot of talk of wanting to hear issues and make change...but precious little real action. Can you go five months without a paycheck? If not...look for a different employer.
